hint.text: Assume the value of \(\pi\) to be \(\frac{22}{7}\)

solution.text:
Consider the given equation : \(\frac{_{{n*7}}_}{11} x + _{j}_y = _{{(j*l) + 2*n}}_\)
Now, for each given ordered pair, substitute the values of x and y and check if it satisfies the equation.
For instance:
\((\pi, _{l}_)\) implies \(x = \pi\) and \(y = _{l}_\)
Substituting the values into the given equation on the Left Hand Side (LHS), we get
\(\frac{_{{n*7}}_}{11} * \pi + _{j}_ * _{l}_ \)
\(= _{{(j*l) + 2*n}}_\)
\(= RHS\)
Hence \((\pi, _{l}_)\) is a solution for the given equation.

Similarly, \((_{{Fraction(11 * ((j*l) + 2*n),(n*7))}}_, 0)\) is also a solution for the given equation but \((_{{Fraction(11 * ((j*l) + n),(n*7))}}_, 0)\) and \((\pi, _{{l+1}}_)\) are not.
